prompt_text:
Create a backward-planned Event Planning Timeline for [ORGANIZATION NAME]’s [EVENT NAME] on [EVENT DATE].

REQUIRED INPUTS (fill these in):
- [ORGANIZATION NAME]: Your nonprofit’s name
- [EVENT NAME]: e.g., “Annual Spring Gala,” “Community Health Fair,” “Donor Breakfast”
- [EVENT DATE]: MM/DD/YYYY
- [EVENT TYPE]: Select one: Gala/Fundraising Dinner | Conference/Summit | Community Festival | Donor Cultivation Event | Auction | Walk/Run | Other: ______
- [EXPECTED ATTENDANCE]: Number (e.g., 75, 250, 500)

OPTIONAL INPUTS (include if relevant):
- [BUDGET RANGE]: e.g., “$5K–10K,” “$25K–50K,” “$100K+” (total event budget)
- [REVENUE TARGET]: e.g., “Net $50K,” “Gross $100K,” “N/A (friend-raising)”
- [SPONSORSHIP GOAL]: e.g., “$30K from 6 sponsors,” “3 x $10K presenting,” “N/A”
- [VENUE TYPE]: e.g., “Hotel ballroom,” “Outdoor park (rain plan),” “Community center,” “Virtual/Hybrid”
- [TEAM SIZE]: e.g., “2 FT + 5 volunteers,” “Solo ED + board committee,” “3-person dev team”
- [AUDIENCE]: e.g., “Major donors,” “Families,” “Corporate partners,” “Alumni”
- [KEY CONSTRAINTS]: e.g., “First-time event,” “Venue must be booked by X,” “Limited AV,” “Board approval >$5K”
- [SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS]: e.g., “Bilingual Spanish/English,” “Kosher,” “ASL,” “Live + silent auction,” “Hybrid”
- [TONE] (applies to entire output; defaults to WARM if not provided): FORMAL | WARM | CASUAL

OUTPUT FORMAT (deliver in two parts):
- PART 1: Executive Summary (200–300 words)
  - Event overview and goals
  - Critical path (top 5–7 must-hit milestones with rationale)
  - Key risks + mitigations (vendor timelines, approvals, weather/tech, budget)
  - Resource summary (team/volunteers/vendors; highlight gaps)
- PART 2: Detailed Timeline Table
  - Columns: Milestone Phase | Task | Owner | Due Date (calendar) | Lead Time | Duration | Dependencies | Priority (P1/P2/P3) | Status (Not Started/In Progress/Blocked/Done) | Notes/Risks (include mitigation) | Cost/Revenue Impact
  - Owner options: Development/Programs/Comms/Finance/ED/Board/Volunteer Lead/Vendor (or specific titles)

TIMELINE ANCHORS (compute actual calendar dates from [EVENT DATE] and show both anchor and date):
- T-6m | T-4m | T-3m | T-2m | T-1m | T-2w | T-1w | Event Day | T+1d | T+1w | T+1m

CONTENT REQUIREMENTS BY PHASE (adapt to event type; keep scope realistic for small teams):
- T-6m (include if [EXPECTED ATTENDANCE] > 150 or [BUDGET RANGE] > $25K; otherwise, condense into T-4m)
  - Venue short-list, site visits, contract signed, deposit paid; insurance/COI requirements noted [LEAD-TIME FLAG]
  - Draft budget + revenue model; approval path (board/finance)
  - Event committee formed; meeting cadence set
  - Save-the-date strategy (channels, list segments); design brief opened [TEMPLATE]
- T-4m
  - Sponsorship track begins: prospect list (20–30), benefits matrix/deck, outreach cadence (email + call every 2 weeks), meeting schedule; goal tracking
  - Vendor RFPs: catering, AV, rentals, printing; compare bids; select vendors; contracts [LEAD-TIME FLAG; add 10–15% buffer] 
  - Permits/licensing (alcohol, park/street use); security if needed [LEAD-TIME FLAG]
- T-3m
  - Marketing/registration launch: platform setup (Eventbrite/Classy/etc.), event page (accessible: alt text, contrast, keyboard nav), email/social/web/partner plan with cadence; conversion checkpoints (25% by T-2m; 60% by T-1m; 85% by T-2w)
  - Sponsorship agreements executed; invoices sent; W-9/ACH details; benefits tracker
  - Program outline: theme, speakers/emcee/honorees holds; initial run-of-show
- T-2m
  - Volunteer roles/descriptions posted; recruitment sources; captain assignments; background checks (2–3 weeks if required)
  - Auction procurement (if applicable): solicitation list, intake form, item descriptions/photos, FMV; tracking sheet [TEMPLATE]
  - Creative/printing briefs (invites, signage, program); sponsor logo/asset deadlines for print/slide inclusion [LEAD-TIME FLAG; add 10–15% buffer]
  - Accessibility plan locked: ASL/interpretation holds; dietary accommodation flow; ADA seating; SSV duty
  - Schedule an Accessibility Audit checkpoint at T-6w (venue ADA, registration form accessibility, wayfinding, sensory considerations)
- T-1m
  - Marketing push: reminder emails, social countdown, partner boosts; press/community calendars
  - Mobile bidding/payment tools configured and tested; merchant account/PCI; backup manual forms
  - Program ad final deadline; slides template to speakers; collect bios/headshots
  - Draft run-of-show v2 with cues; rehearsal date set
- T-2w
  - Final attendance push; catering guarantee submitted (set internal deadline 3–5 days earlier) [LEAD-TIME FLAG]
  - Run-of-show final: scripts, AV cues, fundraising moments (live auction lots, paddle raise levels, pledge text)
  - Volunteer training conducted; comms tree and arrival logistics distributed
  - Signage and printed materials to printer; proof approvals [LEAD-TIME FLAG; 10–15% buffer]
  - Sponsor recognition assets finalized (banners, step-and-repeat, slides, program listings)
- T-1w
  - Logistics lock: floorplan, rentals delivery/pickup windows, load-in/out schedule; parking/transportation plan; coat check
  - Full tech/payment rehearsal; backup hotspots; spare card readers; charging kits
  - Emergency plan (medical/weather/evacuation/tech failure); roles and contacts; incident log template [TEMPLATE]
  - Dietary needs to caterer; seating chart finalized
- Event Day
  - Load-in timeline by vendor; check-in setup; signage placement; brief volunteers; green room/speaker check
  - Execute run-of-show; real-time issue tracker; photo/video capture plan
  - On-site sponsor stewardship; pledge capture verification; end-of-night payment reconciliation start
- T+1d
  - Segmented thank-yous (attendees, donors, sponsors, volunteers, speakers) with photos/link to album
  - Staff/lead volunteer debrief (quick wins/issues); top 3 fixes documented
- T+1w
  - Pledge/AR follow-up; auction item delivery/certificates; expense/revenue reconciliation in progress
  - Sponsor thank-you calls; preliminary impact metrics; fulfillment steps/next touch scheduled
  - Upload CRM data; tag attendees; opt-outs honored [TEMPLATE]
- T+1m
  - Final revenue/expense report; KPIs (attendance vs goal, net, CPDR, sponsor retention, volunteer satisfaction)
  - Sponsor stewardship reports (photos, metrics, quotes); renewal prompts if appropriate
  - Board report; “Template for next year” notes (what worked, vendors, timeline tweaks) [TEMPLATE]

FUNDRAISING ELEMENTS (ensure included where applicable):
- Auction: procurement calendar, item intake/photo, packaging, mobile bidding setup, preview catalog, item pickup/delivery, unsold items plan
- Paddle raise: levels set, impact statements, pledge capture process, MC script, spotters, reconciliation steps
- Payment processing: merchant setup, reader inventory, fee modeling, nightly reconciliation, refund policy

VOLUNTEERS (start T-8–4w):
- Role descriptions, recruitment sources, screening/background checks, shifts, captains, training, comms plan, recognition

LOGISTICS:
- Rentals/floorplan/signage; transportation/parking; dietary needs; sustainability (digital programs, compostables, food donation); contingency/rain plan; emergency roles; COIs

RULES AND QUALITY BARS:
- Calculate and display actual calendar dates for every task based on [EVENT DATE]
- Build 10–15% buffer into external deliverables; flag vendor lead times (venue, catering guarantees, AV, printing, permits, COIs) clearly
- Mark recurring tasks with [TEMPLATE] to enable reuse next year
- Prioritize critical path with Priority levels (P1/P2/P3); note domino effects if delayed
- Tone: use the selected [TONE] (FORMAL/WARM/CASUAL) for the entire output; default is WARM and practical, with clear, jargon-free language

TASK FORMATTING EXAMPLES:
- DO: “Secure venue: tour 3 options, negotiate terms, sign, pay $2,500 deposit — Owner: Development — Due: 02/14/2025 — Lead Time: 6 weeks — Duration: 3 weeks — Dependencies: budget approval — P1 — Notes/Risks: hold expires 2/10; mitigation: internal deadline 2/7 — Cost Impact: $2,500 deposit”
- DO: “Sponsor outreach batch 1: 12 prospects, personalized asks — Owner: Development — Due: 03/01/2025 — Lead Time: 2 weeks — Duration: 5 days — Dependencies: deck approved — P1 — Revenue Impact: est. $15K pipeline”
- DON’T: “Plan logistics” or “Engage stakeholders”

COMPLEXITY ADJUSTMENTS (apply if [EXPECTED ATTENDANCE] > 200 OR [BUDGET RANGE] > $50K):
- Add: professional day-of coordinator, security plan/vendor, additional site visit/walkthrough, valet/traffic control, staging/lighting design, dedicated registration lead, backup internet, additional rehearsal, photo/video shot list, sponsor activation build-outs

DELIVERABLE:
- Provide the 200–300 word Executive Summary followed by a complete timeline table (40–60 specific, dated tasks across all phases). If optional inputs are missing, make reasonable assumptions and state them briefly in the Executive Summary. If any required input is missing, ask for it before proceeding.

This is a CASUAL plan for Otero County Food & Wellness Coalition’s Harvest Health Fair & Block Party.

### PART 1: Executive Summary

Hey team! This plan rockets us toward our first-ever Harvest Health Fair & Block Party on September 21, 2026. This isn't just any block party; it's a Community Festival designed to connect with families and local small businesses in Otero County. We're aiming for 120 attendees and a total budget of $5K–10K, hoping to net $8K, with $5K of that coming from 5 awesome sponsors. Our ideal spot is an outdoor park (with a rain plan!), and it'll be a solo ED + board committee effort. We've got a few quirks to navigate: first-time event, limited rural vendor options, a hard deadline to book our venue by May 1, 2026, limited AV capabilities, and board approval needed for anything over $5K. To make sure everyone feels welcome, we're planning for bilingual Spanish/English support, ASL for the main stage, ADA portable ramps, and keeping it green with compostables only.

Our critical path focuses on securing our venue *fast* to hit that May 1st deadline, nailing down those 5 sponsors early to fuel our efforts, designing a welcoming and accessible program, getting the word out to families, and ensuring we have a smooth, well-rehearsed event day. The biggest risks are vendor lead times in a rural area (mitigated by buffer zones and early outreach), getting board approvals promptly (clear communication and early submissions), and, of course, Mother Nature – hence the rain plan! We'll lean on the ED for overall coordination and the board committee for direct support, especially with sponsorship outreach and on-the-day logistics. Our main gap will be a dedicated volunteer lead, so we’ll need to empower a board member or recruit someone enthusiastically for that role.

evaluation.reasoning: This output successfully delivers a comprehensive, backward-planned timeline that balances casual tone with professional rigor. It demonstrates strong understanding of nonprofit event planning constraints and rural context, though it has minor inconsistencies in task formatting and a few missing elements from the detailed requirements.
strengths: Excellent tone execution - casual yet professional ('Hey team!', 'awesome sponsors', 'Get up early, stay calm!') that fits a small rural nonprofit without sacrificing clarity
Strong contextual adaptation - acknowledges rural vendor limitations, first-time event challenges, and solo ED capacity throughout the plan
Comprehensive critical path identification - correctly prioritizes venue deadline (05/01/2026), sponsorship pipeline, and accessibility requirements with appropriate urgency
Effective use of lead-time flags and buffers - consistently marks vendor-dependent tasks and applies 10-12% buffers as specified
Bilingual and accessibility requirements well-integrated - ASL interpreter, ADA ramps, Spanish/English support appear in multiple phases with specific checkpoints
Realistic task granularity for team size - avoids overwhelming a solo ED with overly complex processes while maintaining necessary rigor
Strong post-event follow-up - includes sponsor stewardship, data management, and template creation for sustainability
Appropriate template markers - identifies reusable documents (save-the-date strategy, emergency plan, CRM upload process) for future efficiency
weaknesses: Executive summary exceeds 300-word limit (approximately 320 words) - should be tightened for busy nonprofit leaders

Missing some granular tasks from prompt requirements - no explicit mention of insurance/COI requirements, conversion checkpoints (25% by T-2m, 60% by T-1m), or specific sponsorship outreach cadence (email + call every 2 weeks)
Table formatting inconsistency - 'Comms负责人' appears instead of 'Comms' in one row (likely encoding error), and some duration estimates seem optimistic (1 day for accessibility audit)
Revenue/cost impact column underutilized - many tasks lack specific dollar amounts or pipeline estimates that would help with budget tracking
Rain plan mentioned multiple times but never detailed - given outdoor venue constraint, should include specific trigger points and alternative logistics
Volunteer recruitment timeline may be tight - starting at T-2m for a first-time event with 10 volunteers needed; T-3m would be safer
Missing explicit food donation/sustainability plan for compostables - requirement mentioned but not operationalized in timeline

outputs.content:
PART 1: Executive Summary (CASUAL)

Event overview and goals
- Host: Otero County Food & Wellness Coalition
- Event: Harvest Health Fair & Block Party (Community Festival)
- Date: 09/21/2026
- Size: 120 attendees (families and local small businesses)
- Assumptions: Outdoor park with a rain plan; limited AV; first-time event; rural vendor options are limited; board approval needed for expenses >$5K. Budget $5K–10K (assume $7.5K), target net $8K with ~$5K from 5 sponsors, plus vendor fees and day-of donations. Bilingual Spanish/English, ASL on main stage, ADA portable ramps, compostables only. Team: Solo ED + board committee + volunteers.

Critical path (must-hit milestones)
1) Board approval + budget lock (by 04/10/26) to greenlight spend and contracts.
2) Venue secured (by 04/29/26) to meet the 05/01/26 requirement and open permits.
3) Permits submitted (by 06/08/26) with 12% timeline buffer due to rural processing.
4) Sponsorship deck + outreach live (by 05/01–05/12/26) to fund early deposits.
5) Marketing/registration launch (by 06/22/26); conversion checkpoints at 7/21, 8/21, 9/7.
6) Vendor selections (rentals/AV/printing/restrooms/power) by 06/19/26 with buffers.
7) Final logistics/tech rehearsal (week of 09/14/26), then lock floorplan and load-in.

Key risks + mitigations
- Vendor lead times/limited options: start RFPs early; hold backups; add 12% time/cost buffer [LEAD-TIME FLAG].
- Weather: tents/rain plan locked; clear go/no-go timeline; park drainage check.
- Approvals: board approval scheduled early; permits in by 06/08.
- Tech/payment: backup hotspots, extra readers, manual forms; limited AV simplified.
- Budget: sponsorship cadence every 2 weeks; printing scope control; compostables bulk order.

Resources
- Team: ED lead; board sponsorship sub-committee; Volunteer Lead (captains, check-in, sustainability).
- Vendors: rentals/stage/PA, restrooms, printer, compost hauler, food trucks; ASL interpreters.
- Gaps: day-of logistics captain preferred; Spanish-language social amplification partners.

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally practical, detailed timeline that a solo ED could actually execute. The casual tone is appropriate and accessible without being unprofessional. It demonstrates deep understanding of small nonprofit constraints and rural context. Minor accuracy concerns around cost estimates and some timeline compression, but overall highly functional.
strengths: Excellent tone calibration: casual, jargon-free, realistic ('keep meetings time-boxed,' 'print-light,' 'if behind, add $75 in boosts') without being cutesy or condescending

Outstanding contextual adaptation: acknowledges 'limited rural vendor options,' 'solo ED + board committee' capacity, first-time event risks, and builds in practical workarounds (digital-first flyers, bulk compostables order, simplified AV)

Highly actionable task formatting: every task includes specific deliverables, realistic durations, clear owners, and concrete cost/revenue impacts (e.g., 'Sponsor outreach batch 1: 12 prospects' not 'engage sponsors')
Strong accessibility integration: ASL, bilingual content, ADA ramps, quiet areas, and sensory considerations are woven throughout rather than tacked on
Excellent use of [TEMPLATE] and [LEAD-TIME FLAG] markers for reusability and risk management—62 tasks with clear dependencies and buffers
Realistic budget modeling: $7.5K spend assumption with itemized vendor costs, 12% buffers, and fee structures (2.9% + $0.30/txn) shows practical financial literacy
Smart prioritization: P1 tasks (venue, permits, sponsorship, accessibility) clearly differentiated from P2/P3; critical path is evident
Post-event follow-up is robust: includes pledge reconciliation, sponsor stewardship reports, CRM tagging, and 'template for next year' documentation
weaknesses: Cost estimates may be optimistic for rural markets: $900 for stage/PA/generator, $600 for printing, $1,300 for rentals/restrooms could run 20-30% higher in areas with limited vendor competition and travel fees

Timeline compression in T-4m phase: collapsing T-6m and T-4m work (venue, budget approval, sponsorship launch) into 8 weeks is aggressive for a first-time event with board approval requirements—could create bottleneck if board meets monthly

Revenue model assumptions need clarification: targeting net $8K on $7.5K budget implies $15.5K gross, but sponsorship ($5K) + booth fees ($1.5K) + day-of donations ($2K est.) = $8.5K, leaving $7K gap unexplained (likely registration fees/vendor revenue not explicitly modeled)
Volunteer recruitment timeline (T-2m start) is tight for rural areas where background checks or health department clearances may be required for food handling roles

# Harvest Health Fair & Block Party — Event Planning Timeline
**Otero County Food & Wellness Coalition | 09/21/2026**

---

## PART 1: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The **Harvest Health Fair & Block Party** is a free community festival targeting families and local small businesses in Otero County, scheduled for September 21, 2026. With an estimated 120 attendees, a total budget of $5K–10K, and a net revenue goal of $8K (supported by $5K from 5 sponsors), this first-time event will be held in an outdoor park with a rain backup plan. The fair aims to promote food security, wellness resources, and community connection through hands-on activities, vendor booths, health screenings, and entertainment. Accessibility features include bilingual Spanish/English materials, ASL interpretation for the main stage, ADA portable ramps, and compostable-only serviceware.

**Critical Path Milestones:**
1. **Venue secured by 05/01/2026** (T-4.7m) — hard deadline per venue policy; delay risks losing site and pushing back all logistics.
2. **Sponsorship agreements signed by 06/15/2026** (T-3.3m) — ensures $5K in revenue; print deadlines depend on confirmed sponsor logos.
3. **Permits finalized by 07/01/2026** (T-2.7m) — park use, food vendor health permits, and potential music licensing; delays halt vendor recruitment.
4. **Volunteer recruitment complete by 08/15/2026** (T-5w) — 15–20 volunteers needed; training must occur T-2w to ensure day-of readiness.
5. **Marketing launch by 06/21/2026** (T-3m) — registration platform live, social/email cadence begins; must hit 60% registration by T-1m to justify vendor/catering commitments.
6. **Catering guarantee submitted by 09/14/2026** (T-1w) — internal deadline set 5 days early to buffer vendor lead time; tied to final attendance count.
7. **ASL/accessibility audit complete by 08/10/2026** (T-6w) — confirms ADA compliance, wayfinding, dietary accommodation workflow.

**Key Risks & Mitigations:**
- **Vendor availability (rural area):** Start RFPs at T-4m; maintain backup lists for catering, AV, rentals, and portable restrooms.
- **Weather contingency:** Secure rain venue hold by T-3m; communicate plan to attendees T-1w; have tarps/tents as fallback.
- **Board approval >$5K:** Route budget and venue contract through board by T-5m to avoid delays.
- **Capacity constraints (solo ED + board committee):** Delegate program/logistics tasks to 2–3 board volunteers; recruit volunteer captains by T-2m; leverage templates for comms/forms to save time.

**Resource Summary:**
- **Staffing:** Solo Executive Director + 4-person board event committee (meeting bi-weekly T-4m through event day).
- **Volunteers:** 15–20 day-of volunteers (check-in, activity stations, setup/breakdown); 2 volunteer captains.
- **Vendors:** Caterer (taco/BBQ trucks or local restaurants), AV (sound system + wireless mics for stage), tent/table/chair rentals, portable restroom company, ASL interpreter (2 hours), print shop (bilingual signage/programs).
- **Gaps:** No dedicated comms or logistics staff; ED will manage sponsor outreach and vendor coordination; board committee absorbs program design and volunteer recruitment. Consider recruiting a pro-bono day-of coordinator from community partners.

## PART 1: Executive Summary

The Pacific Northwest STEM Educators Network (PNSEN) is meticulously planning its **STEM Equity Summit 2026**, a critical Conference/Summit aimed at uniting K–12 district leaders, teachers, corporate tech partners, and university liaisons to advance STEM equity. Scheduled for **April 17, 2026**, this hybrid event targets 350 attendees, leveraging a hotel ballroom with breakout rooms for an immersive experience. The Summit boasts a budget of $50K–100K, with an ambitious fundraising goal of Gross $180K and Net $25K, including $60K from 8 key sponsors. Our dedicated team of 3 full-time staff, augmented by 12 volunteers, will execute this complex event.

**Critical Path Milestones:**
1.  **Venue Contract & Deposit (10/17/2025):** Securing the appropriate venue and finalizing contractual obligations by T-6 months is paramount. Delays here would fundamentally disrupt all subsequent planning.
2.  **Sponsorship Launch & First Agreements (12/17/2025):** Initiating sponsorship outreach by T-4 months and securing initial commitments is vital for budget certainty and leveraging their networks.
3.  **Marketing & Registration Launch (01/17/2026):** Timely public promotion and accessible registration are key to achieving attendance goals, with conversion checkpoints built in.
4.  **Speaker Confirmations & Program Finalization (02/17/2026):** Locking in speakers and the program content by T-2 months ensures rich, relevant content and allows for effective promotion.
5.  **Catering Guarantee & Final Attendee Push (04/03/2026):** Ensuring an accurate headcount for catering by T-2 weeks, alongside a final marketing push, is crucial for financial management and attendance targets.
6.  **Full Tech/Payment Rehearsal (04/10/2026):** Given the hybrid nature and payment collection, a comprehensive rehearsal a week prior is essential to prevent technical failures.

**Key Risks and Mitigations:**
*   **Vendor Timelines:** Contractual clauses will specify penalties for missed deadlines, and a 15% buffer will be applied to all external deliverables. Regular check-ins will be maintained.
*   **Approvals (Board/Budget):** Board approval for expenditures over $5K will be submitted with ample lead time (e.g., 2 weeks prior to required decision date) to avoid bottlenecks.
*   **Technology Failures (Hybrid Event):** A dedicated AV vendor with on-site support, backup internet (hotspots), and a clear incident response plan will be in place. Union AV requirements at the venue will be fully integrated into planning.
*   **Budget Shortfalls:** Proactive sponsorship recruitment and a tiered registration structure will be implemented. Contingency funds will be allocated.

**Resource Summary:** The event relies on 3 FT staff (spanning Development, Programs, Communications), supported by 12 volunteers managed by a Volunteer Lead. Key vendors include the hotel (venue/catering), Union AV, and printers. A professional day-of coordinator will be engaged for seamless execution. Potential gaps exist in dedicated support for accessibility audits and intricate hybrid stream management, which will be addressed through specific vendor contracts and a robust Accessibility Plan.

PART 1: Executive Summary (FORMAL)

Event overview and goals
Pacific Northwest STEM Educators Network will host the STEM Equity Summit 2026 on 04/17/2026 as a 350-person Conference/Summit in a hotel ballroom with breakout rooms and a hybrid plenary stream. Core goals: convene K–12 district leaders, teachers, corporate tech partners, and university liaisons; elevate equitable STEM practices; and secure sponsor/registration revenue to sustain programs. Accessibility is integral: ASL + live captioning, bilingual Spanish/English materials, lactation and quiet rooms, ADA seating/wayfinding, vegetarian/halal options, and hybrid streaming.

Budget and revenue assumptions
Optional inputs indicate Gross $180K; Net $25K with $60K from 8 sponsors. This implies ~ $155K in expenses (i.e., expense band closer to $100K+ despite the $50K–100K range). Action: reconcile and approve final working budget with Finance/Board at T-6m.

Critical path (must-hit milestones)
- Venue contract signed/deposit paid by 10/15/2025; COIs and union AV rules confirmed [LEAD-TIME FLAG].
- Marketing/registration launch 01/17/2026; conversion checkpoints 25% by 02/17, 60% by 03/17, 85% by 04/03.
- Vendor RFPs/selection (catering, AV, printing, rentals, streaming/captioning/ASL) by 12/17/2025; contracts approved (board approval >$5K).
- Program locked: theme/tracks/speakers held by 01/17; run-of-show v2 and rehearsal date by 03/17.
- Accessibility plan locked by 02/17; Accessibility Audit at 03/06.
- Signage/print to printer with 10–15% buffer by 03/29; proofs finalized by 04/03 [LEAD-TIME FLAG].
- Catering guarantee submitted by 04/10 (internal 04/05) [LEAD-TIME FLAG].

Key risks + mitigations
- Vendor/union AV timelines: pre-book, include 15% schedule buffer; obtain COIs early; add backup internet and tech rehearsal.
- Budget variance: seek board approvals early; hold 12% contingency; lock scope at T-1m.
- Hybrid/tech failure: redundant hotspots, spare readers, backup slide laptop; full tech rehearsal at T-1w.
- Speaker travel: book by T-2m; hold refundable fares; confirm ground transport.

Resources
Team: 3 FT + 12 volunteers; add a professional day-of coordinator, dedicated registration lead, and security vendor. Gaps: on-call bilingual translator for onsite signage/messaging; assign AV union liaison. Sponsors: $60K target from 8 sponsors; continue outreach through T-1m. evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally thorough, professional event planning timeline that demonstrates deep understanding of nonprofit conference logistics. The formal tone is consistently maintained, all required elements are present with appropriate complexity adjustments, and the level of detail (60+ tasks with actual calendar dates, dependencies, and risk mitigations) makes this immediately actionable. Minor deductions for occasional template-like language and one budget reconciliation note that could confuse users.
strengths: Outstanding attention to accessibility requirements—ASL, captioning, quiet/lactation rooms, bilingual materials, and ADA audit are woven throughout with specific vendor holds and cost estimates

Excellent application of lead-time flags and buffers (10-15%) on all critical vendor deliverables (union AV, catering guarantees, printing, COIs) with internal vs. external deadlines clearly distinguished
Sophisticated risk mitigation throughout: backup internet/hotspots, spare card readers, refundable speaker travel, attrition date tracking, incident logs, and contingency budget holding
Realistic complexity adjustments for 350-person event: day-of coordinator, security vendor, dedicated registration lead, valet/traffic control, staging/lighting—all appropriate and costed
Strong revenue focus: sponsor pipeline tracking ($60K goal with 8-sponsor mix), conversion checkpoints (25%/60%/85%), exhibitor revenue, payment processing setup, and AR follow-up
Practical template markers ([TEMPLATE]) on reusable assets: registration email series, sponsor deck, run-of-show, incident log, CRM upload process
Formal tone is consistent and appropriate—professional language, precise task descriptions, no casual phrasing, suitable for board/executive review
Executive summary effectively flags the budget discrepancy (Gross $180K implies ~$155K expenses vs. stated $50K-100K range) and requests reconciliation—shows critical thinking
Dependencies and priority levels (P1/P2/P3) are logically assigned; critical path items (venue deposit 10/15, board approvals >$5K, union AV rules) are P1 with appropriate lead times
Hybrid/tech considerations are robust: streaming platform tests, backup encoders, full tech rehearsal, captioning/ASL integration, spare laptops
weaknesses: The Executive Summary budget note ('reconcile and approve final working budget') may confuse users—while it correctly identifies a discrepancy, it could more clearly state whether to use $100K or $155K as the working assumption for the timeline

A few task descriptions lean slightly generic (e.g., 'Marketing push: reminders, partner boosts, calendars') though most are highly specific; adding sample channel mix or partner names would enhance authenticity

The 'Enabled — registration email series, sponsor deck, run-of-show marked [TEMPLATE]' phrase is repeated verbatim in multiple cells, which feels mechanical; varying the language slightly would improve readability

# STEM Equity Summit 2026 – Event Planning Timeline
**Pacific Northwest STEM Educators Network | April 17, 2026**

---

## PART 1: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The STEM Equity Summit 2026 will convene 350 K–12 district leaders, teachers, corporate tech partners, and university liaisons on April 17, 2026, in a hybrid hotel ballroom setting. The event targets $180K gross revenue and $25K net, with $60K from eight corporate sponsors (2 × $15K, 4 × $7.5K, 2 × $5K) and an estimated $50K–100K total budget. The summit advances equity in STEM education through keynote sessions, breakout workshops, and networking, with robust accessibility features including ASL interpretation, live captioning, bilingual Spanish/English materials, lactation and quiet rooms, diverse dietary options, and hybrid streaming.

**Critical Path Milestones:**

1. **Venue Contract & Deposit (10/15/2025, T-6m):** Venue deposit deadline is contractually fixed; delay jeopardizes room block and AV setup. Union AV requirements demand early coordination.
2. **Sponsorship Deck & Outreach Launch (12/17/2025, T-4m):** Securing $60K from eight sponsors requires 12–16 weeks of cultivation; delays compress follow-up cycles and risk revenue shortfall.
3. **Registration & Marketing Launch (01/17/2026, T-3m):** Platform accessibility (alt text, keyboard navigation, contrast) and bilingual content require three weeks' setup; late launch prevents reaching 60% registration by T-1m.
4. **Speaker Travel Support & Accessibility Holds (02/17/2026, T-2m):** Airline pricing escalates closer to event; ASL/captioning vendors book out 8–10 weeks ahead.
5. **Catering Guarantee Submission (04/03/2026, T-2w):** Hotel contract mandates final counts 14 days prior; internal deadline April 1 buffers last-minute registrations.
6. **Volunteer Training & Tech Rehearsal (04/10/2026, T-1w):** Hybrid streaming, mobile check-in, and accessibility protocols require full run-through to avoid day-of failures.
7. **Board Approval for Contracts >$5K (by 11/01/2025):** AV, catering, and speaker travel contracts trigger governance threshold; late approval cascades to all vendor timelines.

**Key Risks & Mitigations:**

- *Vendor Lead Times:* Union AV, hotel F&B, and ASL interpreter availability are 8–12 week minimums. **[LEAD-TIME FLAG]** All contracts include force majeure clauses; backup interpreter agency identified.
- *Budget Constraints:* 15% buffer applied to all external costs; monthly finance reviews track variance. Slippage >12% escalates to ED/Board.
- *Hybrid Technology:* Internet redundancy (hardline + two hotspots), dedicated streaming tech, and backup recording plan mitigate connectivity failures.
- *Sponsorship Pipeline:* If 50% of $60K goal not secured by T-3m, activate contingency outreach to 10 additional prospects and reduce non-essential AV.

**Resource Summary:**

- **Team:** 3 FT staff (Development Director, Programs Manager, Communications Coordinator) + 12 volunteers (roles: registration, session support, speaker liaisons, accessibility ambassadors).
- **Vendors:** Hotel (venue/catering), union AV, ASL/captioning provider, printing, hybrid streaming platform.
- **Gaps:** No dedicated day-of coordinator budgeted; Programs Manager assumes role. If registration exceeds 300 by T-1m, hire temp event support ($800–1,200).

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally comprehensive and professional event planning timeline that demonstrates deep understanding of nonprofit operations, accessibility requirements, and complex event logistics. The output meticulously follows the formal tone requested, includes all required elements with actual calculated dates, and provides actionable, specific tasks that a real events team could implement immediately. Minor deductions for occasional over-complexity that might overwhelm smaller teams and some repetitive phrasing.
strengths: Outstanding attention to accessibility throughout - ASL, captioning, quiet rooms, dietary needs, lactation space, and a dedicated T-6w accessibility audit checkpoint show genuine expertise
Excellent use of lead-time flags and buffers (15% on vendors, 12% on budget) with specific mitigation strategies for each risk - demonstrates real-world event planning experience
Highly actionable task formatting with all required columns populated accurately, including actual calendar dates, dependencies, cost impacts, and specific owner assignments
Strong integration of fundraising elements (sponsorship pipeline tracking, conversion checkpoints at 25%/60%/85%, revenue reconciliation) appropriate for the $180K gross/$25K net target
Comprehensive post-event follow-up including segmented thank-yous, stewardship reports, CRM data management, and template documentation for future years
Realistic resource allocation acknowledging team constraints (notes when to escalate, when to hire temp support, backup plans for volunteer shortfalls)
Bilingual and hybrid requirements woven throughout rather than treated as afterthoughts - shows cultural competency
Template markers [TEMPLATE] strategically placed on reusable assets (email series, run-of-show, sponsorship deck) for operational efficiency
weaknesses: The 60-task timeline, while comprehensive, may be overwhelming for the stated 3 FT + 12 volunteer team - could benefit from a 'critical path only' condensed version for quick reference
Some task descriptions are quite lengthy and could be more scannable - the table format works better with tighter language in the Notes/Risks column
Minor inconsistency: T+1m tasks show due dates in early May (05/10-05/20) but the phase header says 05/17/2026 - creates slight confusion on the anchor date
The Executive Summary, while excellent, runs slightly long at ~320 words vs. the 200-300 word target

## PART 1: Executive Summary

The Harbor City Children’s Hospital Foundation is celebrating a significant milestone with its 50th Anniversary Gala & Auction on November 14, 2026. This Gala, targeting 600 attendees, aims to net an ambitious $1.2 million, with $750,000 sourced from 12 key sponsors (3 x $100K presenting, 3 x $50K, 6 x $25K). The event will be hosted at a unionized hotel ballroom, requiring meticulous planning around union labor rules and strict load-in windows. Professional staging, lighting, and valet services are planned to enhance the attendee experience, alongside a live and silent auction, paddle raise, ASL interpretation, and specialized dietary options.

Our critical path is centered on securing the venue with a paid deposit by May 14, 2026, launching our comprehensive sponsorship drive by June 14, 2026, implementing a robust multi-channel marketing and registration campaign by August 14, 2026, locking in our catering guarantee by October 27, 2026 (internal deadline), and developing an ironclad run-of-show including fundraising mechanisms by October 31, 2026. These milestones are interdependent and crucial for reaching our financial and attendance goals.

Key risks include vendor lead times, particularly for the unionized hotel and AV services, which will be mitigated by building 10-15% buffer into all external deliverables and securing COIs from all vendors. Our team, consisting of 6 full-time Development staff, an Events Manager, and 40 dedicated volunteers, is well-positioned for success. evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly professional, comprehensive event timeline that demonstrates strong understanding of complex gala planning. The output successfully balances warm, accessible language with the sophistication required for a major hospital foundation event. Minor gaps in task specificity and some timeline compression prevent a perfect score, but this would be immediately actionable for an experienced events team.
strengths: Excellent executive summary that clearly articulates critical path, risks, and mitigation strategies in accessible language appropriate for both board and staff audiences
Comprehensive timeline with 40+ specific, dated tasks that reflect genuine understanding of high-stakes gala logistics (union rules, VIP security, COI requirements, catering guarantees)
Strong adherence to lead-time flagging and buffer requirements—consistently applies 10-15% buffers and marks vendor dependencies clearly
Realistic resource allocation and task ownership that reflects the stated team structure (6 FT dev staff + Events Manager + volunteers)
Thoughtful integration of accessibility requirements (ASL, dietary, ADA audit checkpoint) and high-security VIP protocols throughout timeline
Effective use of [TEMPLATE] markers for reusable assets (sponsor matrix, emergency plan, thank-you series, CRM upload) that support institutional knowledge
Revenue tracking woven throughout with specific pipeline management tasks and clear connection to $1.2M net goal and $750K sponsorship target
Post-event follow-up is detailed and realistic, including AR collection, sponsor stewardship reports, and board reporting with lessons learned
weaknesses: Timeline table occasionally lacks the granular specificity promised in prompt examples—some tasks like 'RFP for catering, AV, rentals' could be broken into separate line items with distinct owners and dependencies

T-6m phase feels slightly compressed given the scale (600 attendees, $100K+ budget)—venue deposit timeline of 2 weeks from shortlist to signed contract is aggressive for a union hotel requiring complex negotiations

Missing a few complexity adjustments explicitly called for in the prompt: no dedicated day-of coordinator task, no security vendor RFP/contract line item (only mentioned in notes), no valet/traffic control planning task despite being listed in venue type
Cost/Revenue Impact column is inconsistently populated—some high-impact items (AV contracts, entertainment, security) show 'N/A' when estimates would be valuable for budget tracking
Auction procurement timeline (starting T-2m for a $200K+ goal at a major gala) may be too late—sophisticated events typically begin item solicitation at T-4m to T-3m
Duration estimates for some tasks seem optimistic (e.g., '3 days' for finalizing run-of-show with fundraising moments, scripts, and AV cues for a 600-person gala with live auction and paddle raise)

PART 1: Executive Summary (WARM)
Harbor City Children’s Hospital Foundation will host its 50th Anniversary Gala & Auction on 11/14/2026, a Gala/Fundraising Dinner for 600 guests. Goals: celebrate 50 years of impact, deepen relationships with major donors/corporate leaders/grateful families, and net $1.2M. Revenue pillars: $750K from 12 sponsors (3 x $100K presenting, 3 x $50K, 6 x $25K), live + silent auction, and paddle raise. The venue is a union hotel ballroom with staging/lighting and valet; we’ll operate within limited load-in windows, strict house rules, and a 10% schedule buffer. We will maintain a 12% cost contingency and 15% buffer on print assets.

Critical path (must-hit): 
- Board-approved budget + contracting thresholds (unlocks vendors).
- Hotel contract + insurance/COIs (union rules; load-in windows).
- Sponsorship launch and closes (funding engine; benefits delivery).
- Marketing/registration launch (hit 25% by T-2m, 60% by T-1m, 85% by T-2w).
- AV/staging/lighting design lock + rehearsal (program success).
- Auction procurement + mobile bidding build (fundraising).
- Final run-of-show, catering guarantee by 10/31, and full tech/payment rehearsal.

Key risks + mitigations: 
- Vendor lead times/union constraints: [LEAD-TIME FLAG] items locked early; 10–15% schedule buffers. 
- High-security VIPs: dedicated security vendor + venue/VIP briefings; credentialing.
- Tech/payment failure: backup hotspots, spare readers, paper forms; dress rehearsal.
- Branding/print delays: 15% buffer; internal approvals early.
- Budget creep: 12% contingency; finance checkpoints.

Resources: Development (6 FT) + Events Manager + 40 volunteers; hotel catering; AV/staging; security; valet; photo/video; auctioneer/mobile bidding; ASL; printers; décor/florals; professional day-of coordinator; registration lead; stage manager. Gaps covered: security coordinator function, dedicated registration lead, and stage manager included in plan.

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally thorough and professional event planning timeline that demonstrates deep understanding of complex gala logistics. The output successfully balances comprehensive detail with practical usability, includes all required elements, and appropriately addresses the sophisticated needs of a major hospital foundation event. Minor weaknesses include some repetitive phrasing and a slightly mechanical feel in places, but overall it would be immediately actionable for the target organization.
strengths: Outstanding attention to critical path dependencies and risk mitigation—security protocols, union labor rules, VIP considerations, and vendor lead times are all appropriately flagged and buffered
Excellent calendar date calculations throughout (all dates correctly computed backward from 11/14/2026) with realistic lead times for a 600-person, $1.2M net revenue gala
Comprehensive coverage of complex fundraising mechanics (live/silent auction, paddle raise with spotters, mobile bidding, payment reconciliation) with appropriate technical detail
Strong accessibility integration (ASL, dietary accommodations, ADA seating, dedicated accessibility audit checkpoint at T-6w) that goes beyond checkbox compliance
Appropriate warm-but-professional tone that respects the sophistication of the audience while remaining practical and jargon-free
Intelligent prioritization system (P1/P2/P3) with clear dependencies that would help a team sequence work effectively
Realistic resource allocation acknowledging the complexity (professional day-of coordinator, stage manager, registration lead, 40 volunteers, security vendor)
Excellent use of [LEAD-TIME FLAG] and [TEMPLATE] markers that enable reuse and highlight critical vendor timelines
Strong post-event follow-up sequence including segmented thank-yous, sponsor stewardship reports, and 'template for next year' documentation
Executive summary effectively distills critical path, risks, and resource needs in accessible language
weaknesses: Some task descriptions are slightly formulaic or repetitive in structure (e.g., multiple 'RFP: [vendor]; compare; select; contract' entries could be more varied)
The 'Cost/Revenue Impact' column occasionally uses placeholder language ('TBD,' 'major vendor') where more specific estimates or ranges would add value, even if approximate

A few tasks could benefit from more granular owner assignments—'Development' is used broadly when specific roles (Major Gifts Officer, Events Coordinator) might clarify accountability in a 6-person team
Minor inconsistency: the Executive Summary states 'Gaps covered' but doesn't explicitly identify what the original gaps were before stating they're now covered

# Harbor City Children's Hospital Foundation  
## 50th Anniversary Gala & Auction — November 14, 2026  
### Event Planning Timeline (Backward-Planned)

---

## PART 1: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

**Event Overview & Goals**  
The Harbor City Children's Hospital Foundation's 50th Anniversary Gala & Auction on November 14, 2026, will celebrate five decades of healing with 600 major donors, corporate leaders, philanthropists, and grateful families in a hotel ballroom (union house) with full staging and lighting. The event targets net revenue of $1.2M through ticket sales, a $750K sponsorship program (3 × $100K presenting, 3 × $50K, 6 × $25K), and live/silent auction plus paddle raise. The program includes ASL interpretation, kosher-style and gluten-free menus, step-and-repeat, and professional photo/video capture. A 6-FT development team, events manager, and 40 volunteers will execute under a $100K+ budget.

**Critical Path (Must-Hit Milestones)**  
1. **Venue Contract Signed (05/14/2026, T-6m):** Union house requires load-in coordination; hold expires quickly; any delay cascades vendors and catering guarantee.  
2. **Sponsor Agreements Executed (07/14/2026, T-4m):** $750K represents 63% of net goal; late execution jeopardizes print deadlines and sponsor benefits fulfillment.  
3. **Catering Guarantee Submitted (10/31/2026, T-2w internal):** Hotel contractual deadline; internal target 10/28 to absorb late RSVPs.  
4. **Auction Procurement Complete (09/14/2026, T-2m):** Mobile bidding catalog preview launches T-1m; late items miss donor engagement window.  
5. **Volunteer Training Conducted (10/28/2026, T-2.5w):** 40 volunteers span check-in, auction spotting, accessibility, donor stewardship; untrained volunteers risk donor experience and pledge capture.  
6. **Run-of-Show Final (10/31/2026, T-2w):** AV cues, ASL sync, paddle raise script, VIP escort protocol; late changes incur union labor penalties.  
7. **Board Approvals for >$5K Expenditures (06/14/2026, T-5m):** Major vendor contracts (AV, catering, rentals) require formal board sign-off; any delay stalls RFPs.

**Key Risks & Mitigations**  
• **Vendor Lead Times:** Union labor rules limit load-in windows; mitigation: internal deadlines 10% earlier, confirmed load-in schedule by T-3m.  
• **VIP Security:** High-net-worth attendees require discrete security; mitigation: hire licensed vendor by T-4m, conduct walk-through T-2w.  
• **Sponsorship Pipeline:** $750K from 12 sponsors is ambitious; mitigation: prospect list of 30 (2.5× target), biweekly outreach cadence, tracking dashboard reviewed weekly.  
• **Catering Guarantee Timing:** Hotel penalty for late count; mitigation: internal deadline 10/28 (3 days before contractual), final attendance push T-3w.  
• **COI Delays:** All vendors require certificates of insurance; mitigation: COI request sent with contract signature, tracked in shared sheet, escalation to ED if not received T-4w.  
• **Accessibility Audit Gap:** ASL, dietary, ADA seating complex; mitigation: dedicated accessibility audit T-6w (10/01/2026) with checklist and remediation budget reserve.

**Resource Summary**  
• **Internal:** 6 FT development staff, events manager (lead), 40 trained volunteers (recruitment starts T-8w). **Gap:** Day-of coordinator (recommend hire T-3m, ~$3K).  
• **External:** Union venue, full-service caterer, AV/staging, mobile bidding platform, security (2 officers), valet, ASL interpreter, photo/video crew, printing vendor.  
• **Board/Committee:** Event committee (8 members) meets monthly T-6m onward; finance committee approves budget T-6m, major contracts T-5m.  
• **Volunteers:** 40 across shifts (setup 2pm, event 5–10pm, breakdown); roles: registration (8), auction spotting (6), VIP escort (4), accessibility (2), coat check (4), general hospitality (12), breakdown (4). Captains assigned T-4w.

**END OF TIMELINE**

**Notes:**
- **Total Tasks:** 60 detailed, dated tasks spanning T-6m (05/14/2026) through T+1m (12/14/2026).
- **Calendar Dates:** All due dates calculated backward from Event Day (11/14/2026).
- **Lead-Time Flags:** Venue, permits, AV design, catering guarantee, printing, security, insurance, COIs marked with [LEAD-TIME FLAG].
- **Templates:** Sponsorship deck, scripts, pledge forms, emergency plan, volunteer training materials, debrief notes, playbook marked with [TEMPLATE] for reuse.
- **Buffers:** 10% schedule buffer on external vendor deadlines; 12% cost contingency in budget; 15% buffer on print/production due to branding approvals.
- **Accessibility:** ASL, dietary accommodations, ADA seating, quiet room, accessibility audit T-6w integrated throughout.
- **Fundraising:** $750K sponsorship (12 sponsors), $200K auction, $150K paddle raise, $150K tickets = $1.25M gross; $100K expenses = $1.15M net (pending final AR).
- **Tone:** WARM—practical, clear, jargon-free, with donor-centric and mission-focused language throughout.

This timeline is ready for immediate use by the Harbor City Children's Hospital Foundation development team. Adjust task owners, dates, and priorities as your team's capacity and vendor availability dictate. 🎉

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally comprehensive and professional event planning timeline that demonstrates deep understanding of complex nonprofit fundraising events. The output expertly balances granular tactical detail with strategic oversight, using warm but professional language throughout. Minor verbosity in some task descriptions is the only notable weakness, but this actually enhances clarity for less-experienced users.
strengths: Outstanding executive summary that immediately orients the user with critical path, risks, and resource gaps—exactly what a development director needs to brief leadership

Exceptional attention to realistic operational details: union labor rules, COI tracking, load-in windows, ADA compliance audit, payment reconciliation, and vendor lead-time buffers demonstrate real-world event experience
Brilliant use of specific, actionable task formatting with clear owners, dependencies, and mitigation strategies (e.g., 'internal deadline 10/28 = 3 days buffer' for catering guarantee)
Comprehensive fundraising integration: sponsorship pipeline tracking, auction procurement calendar, paddle raise mechanics, and AR follow-up are all properly sequenced
Strong accessibility planning throughout (ASL, dietary, ADA seating, quiet room, T-6w audit checkpoint) rather than treating it as an afterthought
Excellent use of [TEMPLATE] and [LEAD-TIME FLAG] markers to build institutional knowledge and flag critical dependencies
Revenue and cost impacts clearly noted in nearly every task, enabling budget tracking and ROI analysis
Realistic volunteer management: recruitment timeline, background checks, captain structure, training, and day-of coordination
Post-event stewardship and data management tasks are thorough and donor-centric (segmented thank-yous, sponsor reports, CRM tagging, renewal pipeline)
Tone is consistently warm, practical, and jargon-free while maintaining professionalism appropriate for a major hospital foundation
weaknesses: Some task descriptions are quite lengthy and could be condensed for at-a-glance scanning (e.g., the 'Notes/Risks' column sometimes reads like full paragraphs rather than bullets)
A few minor redundancies: the executive summary mentions 'critical path' milestones that are then repeated verbatim in the timeline table—could streamline by referencing table in summary
The 60-task table, while comprehensive, may be overwhelming for smaller teams to adapt; a 'quick-start' version for orgs with <200 attendees would enhance accessibility

Minor authenticity concern: the level of polish and completeness is almost *too* perfect—real event timelines evolve messily, and acknowledging iteration (e.g., 'this is v1; expect updates after committee review') would feel more genuine
